The Cabinet considered a memorandum by the Lord(Previous President (C. (54) 395) outlining a programme for the development ofReference: power from atomic energy for civil purposes, and seeking authorityCC. (54) 79th for an immediate start on a civil programme on these lines.Conclusions, The Lord president said that it was now established that the" 11 ! generation of electricity from atomic energy was technically feasibleCivil and was likely to prove, within the next ten years, competitive withProgramme. electricity generated by conventional methods. The full programmeof development, which had been worked out with the departments directly concerned, would involve capital expenditure of 300 millions over ten years. At present, however, he sought authority only forthe first stage of the programme, viz., the construction of two power stations, to be completed by 1960, at a cost of 50 millions. Theremainder of the programme would be open to review in the light of developments. This civil programme would not compete with military requirements for fissile material, which were covered up to1960 by facilities already existing or under construction.The Chancellor of the Exchequer said that the successfuldevelopment of atomic power for civil purposes was of crucial importance to the future of the national economy. He thereforewelcomed the proposals put forward by the Lord President, on theunderstanding that the Cabinet would not at present be committed to expenditure beyond the initial outlay of 50 millions.The Minister of Defence also supported these proposals, on theunderstanding that they would not prejudice the arrangements to be.made for meeting military requirements for fissile material after 1960.47403-1 b 2House o 1. (54) 55th In discussion it was pointed out that the Government had conclusions, acquired this site compulsorily for the purpose of building a newMinute 8.) Government Office and could not now, without legislation, use it fora different purpose. There would also be practical difficulties inclearing the whole of the larger area which the Prime Minister hadin mind. This would involve, in particular, acquiring the offices of the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors, which was shortly to be rebuilt; and this alone would probably increase to 5 millionsthe cost of acquiring the necessary land. Moreover, it would be many years before the buildings on the south side of Great george street could be reconstructed in conformity with such a plan.Meanwhile, it was very desirable that the Colonial Office shouldbe moved from the temporary accommodation in which it was nowhoused; and it would not be easy to find suitable permanent accommodation for it if the original project was abandoned.Possible alternatives were to construct a building which wouldaccommodate both the Colonial Office and the commonwealth relations Office on the site in Carlton House Terrace now earmarked for a new Foreign Office building, or to provide for the ColonialOffice on the Horseferry Road site now in course of development.The Cabinet (1) Invited the Minister of Works to arrange for members ofthe Cabinet to see a scale model showing how the westminster site would look if the present plan for thenew Colonial Office building were completed.(2) Agreed to resume their discussion of this question at a later meeting.Price of Sugar.(previous reference:C.C. (54) 82ndConclusions,Minute 5.)7. The Cabinet considered a memorandum by the Chancellorof the Exchequer (C. (54) 397) reporting the conclusions which hehad reached, after consultation with the Minister of Food, on the suggestions put forward in the Cabinefs discussion on 6th Decemberwith a view to avoiding an early increase in the retail price of sugar.The Chancellor of the Exchequer said that he was satisfied thatan increase in the retail price could not be avoided by transferringGovernment stocks of sugar to the strategic stockpile. The most that could be so transferred would be 500,000 tons. This wouldinvolve a Supplementary Estimate for 21-7 millions and would not,even so, avert a substantial trading loss. Nor was it possible to ask the sugar refiners to meet from their profits the proposed increasein the wholesale price of sugar. Though their total profits were large, their margin on sales in the United Kingdom was not highand could not reasonably be reduced. In these circumstances he Cabinet Office, S.W.1,21st December, 1954.saw no alternative to his original proposal that the price at whichthe Government sold sugar to the refiners should be increased byan amount which would have the result of raising the retail priceby \d. a lb. He would, however, be ready to consider the timing of this increase, in consultation with the other Ministers most directly concerned.In discussion it was recognised that the Government were boundto incur criticism if, as a result of their heavy purchases before sugarwas derrationed, the retail price of sugar in this country was increased at a time when the world price of sugar was falling. The point wasalso made that, as the price of tea had also risen, it would be preferable that any increase in the price of sugar should be delayedfor a time-possibly until the new rates of National Assistance werein operation, On the other hand, if this price increase was inevitable,there were political arguments in favour of allowing it to come intooperation earlier rather than laier.The Cabinet -(1) Agreed in principle that the price at which the Governmentsold sugar to refiners in this country should be increasedby an amount which was likely to lead to an increase of%d. a lb. in the retail price of sugar.(2) Invited the Chancellor of the Exchequer to consider the timing of this price increase, in consultation with the other ministers most directly concerned, and to submit theirviews for the Prime Minister^ approval.
